title: Plastic pollution to weigh 1.3 billion tonnes by 2040 - BBC
body: Getty Images The single biggest use of plastics is in packaging and it tends to be used just once before being thrown away An estimated 1.3 billion tonnes of plastic is destined for our...
readable_content: - BBC News (2023-12-08): Plastic pollution is projected to reach 1.3 billion tonnes by 2040 if no global action is taken, according to a study published in the journal Science. The researchers highlighted the need to reduce plastic production and consumption, substitute plastic with other materials, design products for recycling, improve waste collection rates in low-income countries, and support waste pickers. Even with feasible action, it's expected that 710 million extra tonnes of plastic waste will be in the environment in the next two decades. The study also emphasized the lack of proper waste management for an estimated 2 billion people in the Global South and the need to support waste pickers for a comprehensive solution.
summary:
The article emphasizes the urgent need for global action to address the growing plastic pollution crisis. It underscores the importance of reducing plastic production and consumption, improving waste management, and supporting waste pickers. The sentiment about banning plastic straws aligns with the need to reduce overall plastic usage and improve waste management.
